author: Phillip Coorey
title: Paul Howes calls for end to bloody battle between unions and bosses
text:
Paul Howes: "The constantly changing rule book on industrial relations in Australia creates a culture of perpetual instability." Darrian Traynor Share on twitter by Phillip Coorey After a year in the corporate world, former union leader Paul Howes says business is equally as responsible as unions for the "toxic culture" that underpins the approach to workplace relations, which ultimately stymies productivity.
Mr Howes, now a partner at KPMG, will use a speech on Friday to agree there needs to be changes to industrial relations laws but a far greater solution is needed to end what has become "a bloody battle to the death" that is dragging the country down.
He will repeat the call he made in February 2014, in his last big speech as national secretary of the Australian Workers Union, for a grand compact between business and the unions in which engagement and consultation replace warfare.
Back then, Mr Howes said rather than constantly fiddling with the laws to suit whichever party was in power, there needed to a compact lasting up to 20 years.
The speech excoriated both sides of politics, including his own, which he chipped for decrying every Coalition policy utterance as WorkChoices and acknowledged the Fair Work Act had resulted in unsustainable wages growth in some industries, such as offshore oil and gas.
On Friday, Mr Howes will tell a conference in Melbourne that "yes, there may be a case for changes to the [industrial relations] legislation now ... but the point I was making early last year, and now, is that the blockages that exist on our pathway to productivity growth won't be cleared by yet another change to the legislation".
Perpetual instability The speech will be Mr Howes' first public foray into a policy debate since he quit the AWU in March last year but he stresses it does not signal any plans to re-enter the political arena.
 "The constantly changing rule book on industrial relations in Australia creates a culture of perpetual instability," he will say.
"Both business and labour believe, quite reasonably, that you don't need to engage and play that game as it's meant to be played, because you can probably change the rules to your advantage soon anyway.
"To ensure this, both sides engage in wild, overhyped claims about how disastrous the current legislation is."
Mr Howes will say that now he has witnessed life from the other side of the fence, "unfortunately, it doesn't look too unfamiliar".
"It's clear that it isn't just the union side that is unnecessarily suspicious.
"I have seen the stubbornness and the resistance to new ideas that exist within elements of the union movement.
"But it is just as prevalent within some parts of our management sector."
Mr Howes notes that nations such as Switzerland and Singapore which rate at the top of the World Economic Forum's global competitiveness rankings also at the top in terms of labour-employer co-operation because of their more open and consultative approach involving stakeholders..
Other top performers include the Netherlands, Japan, Germany Canada and Norway, some of which have more regulated labour markets than Australia and some have less.
"It is not as simple as saying that simply deregulating the labour market as far as politically possible is the key to global competitiveness," he will say.
"Healing our catastrophically poor labour-employer relations, therefore, is fundamental to our economic performance."
